intro: Guindilia dissecta, commonly known as the dissected guindilia, is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, pentagonal flowers. The plant has palmate leaves with deeply lobed segments, giving it a distinctive, fern-like appearance. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in cloud forests at higher elevations. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens and by plant enthusiasts.
